dt: {bc}to recover (property) from a person by legal process
{bc}to put (a tenant) out by legal process

pt: {sc}eject{/sc} {sc}expel{/sc} {sc}oust{/sc} {sc}evict{/sc} mean to drive or force out. {sc}eject{/sc} carries an especially strong implication of throwing or thrusting out from within as a physical action.

pt.t: {it}ejected{/it} an obnoxious patron from the bar

pt: {sc}expel{/sc} stresses a thrusting out or driving away especially permanently which need not be physical.
{sc}oust{/sc} implies removal or dispossession by power of the law or by force or compulsion.
{sc}evict{/sc} chiefly applies to turning out of house and home.

et: Middle English, from Late Latin {it}evictus{/it}, past participle of {it}evincere{/it}, from Latin, to vanquish, win a point {ma}{mat|evince|}{/ma}
shortdef: to recover (property) from a person by legal process
to put (a tenant) out by legal process
